definition: to cross/to go over/to pass (time)/to celebrate (a holiday)/to live/to get along/excessively/too-
classifier for gifts, newspaper, magazine, papers, reports, contracts etc/variant of 分[fen4]

sentences.english: She allowed him to hold her hand, but forbade him any intimacies.
sentences.chinese: 她让他握着手，但不许他有过份亲密的行动。

sentences.english: Has the hate for dirt, however, gone too far?
sentences.chinese: 然而，必欲到“垢”而后快，也太过份了吧？

sentences.english: I think market share has been overemphasized here at ACME.
sentences.chinese: 我认为ACME过份强调市场份额了。

sentences.english: Readers should not over-emphasize the relative ranking of different institutions.
sentences.chinese: 读者不宜过份集中比较院校之间的排名。

sentences.english: And I just think that's asking the jury to grasp ahold of a little bit too much.
sentences.chinese: 我只是觉得要求陪审团掌握这些东西有一点过份了。

sentences.english: For this reason, over-fishing of sharks is a danger to the future of the animal.
sentences.chinese: 对于这个原因，过份捕鲨鱼对这个动物未来说很危险。

sentences.english: Don't be too confident ial with strangers.
Not much for them to worry about, then.
sentences.chinese: 于是也就不用为他们过份担心。

sentences.english: Cox and others, however, intentionally over-emphasize the use of computers in the military field.
sentences.chinese: 但考克斯等人有意过份强调计算机在军事方面的用途。

sentences.english: So much of that thing has been done by these reckless Abolitionists.
sentences.chinese: 那些轻举妄动的废奴派做得实在太过份了。

sentences.english: She never talked too loudly of earls and countesses .
sentences.chinese: 她从来没有过份高声地谈到伯爵和伯爵夫人。

sentences.english: The overemphasize of quantity of papers does have negative effect on research.
sentences.chinese: 过份重视文章的数量，对研究有负面的效果。

sentences.english: Excessive sympathetic drive is by far the most common cause of sinus tachycardia.
sentences.chinese: 过份的交感冲动是窦性心动过速最常见的原因。

definition: to force someone to do something
to overstep the bounds of what is proper/to take sth too far/(of a measuring device) to go off the scale
to go too far (in word or deed)/over the top
variant of 小題大做|小题大做[xiao3 ti2 da4 zuo4]
to act arbitrarily regardless of the rules/to mess with sth/to make a hash of things/to cause trouble
to feel embarrassed or awkward/to make things difficult (for someone)/to find things difficult (to do or manage)
